DataElement.preferredName: Invasive Lobular Breast Carcinoma In Situ Extent Category
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text description and numeric percentage of the extent of LCIS associated with invasive cancer.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to invasive LCIS diagnosis.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: marked by a tendency to spread especially into healthy tissue.:Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS, intralobular carcinoma, lobular neoplasia) is characterized by a proliferation of monomorphic cells completely filling the lumina.  The overall lobular architecture is preserved.  LCIS is frequently multifocal (90% in some series) and bilateral.  LCIS seldom becomes invasive, however there is an increased risk of infiltrating ductal adenocarcinoma.  --2002

Concepts.definition: Marked by a tendency to spread, especially into healthy surrounding tissue.

A non-invasive adenocarcinoma of the breast characterized by a proliferation of monomorphic cells completely filling the lumina.  The overall lobular architecture is preserved.  It is frequently multifocal (90% in some series) and bilateral.  It seldom becomes invasive; however there is an increased risk of infiltrating ductal adenocarcinoma.

Property.preferredDefinition: The process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms.

Concepts.definition: The investigation, analysis and recognition of the presence and nature of disease, condition, or injury from expressed signs and symptoms; also, the scientific determination of any kind; the concise results of such an investigation.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).
